Departing/leaving the hold at set time    
When clearance is received that specifies the time of depature form the holding point, the pilot should adjust the pattern within the limits of the established holding procedure in order to leave the holding point at the time specified.

## Altimeter Setting Procedures

Standardised altimeter setting --> vertical separation between aircraft and adequate terrain (obstacle) clearance during all phases of flight.

Below or at **transition altitude**, aircraft is flown at altitudes based on altimeter setting to MSL, i.e., QNH. Vertical position = altitude.

Above **transition altitude**, aircraft flown on standard constant atmospheric pressure of 1013.25hPa ~ flight levels FL.

Where no transition altitude has been established for the area (e.g. remote areas), aircraft in the enroute phase must be flown at flight levels FL (standard pressure setting of 1013.25hPa)

Altimeter settings provided to aircraft shall be rounded DOWN to nearest whole hectopascal.

### Transition Altitude & Transition Level

Transition altitude is the altitude below which the vertical position of the aircraft is controlled by altitudes above mean sea level MSL.

TA must be specified for each aerodrome by the State in which the aerodrome is located.    
In practice, and to avoid confusion, transition altitudes are normally standardised for the whole FIR.

Whereas the transition altitude is fixed, the **transition level** changes based on QNH/air pressure. ATC to determine the transition level.    
- calculated height of the transition altitude is rounded up to the next full 1000ft (e.g. 3300ft --> 4000ft).

Transition altitudes "as low as possible", but normally not less than 3000ft.

Nearby aerodromes - coordination for common transition altitude = highest transition altitude if considered separately.

Transition altitudes are published in AIP and shown on approach charts.

**transition level** change in reference from altitude on QNH to flight levels (standard pressure).

Transition level = lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude.

An aircraft in descent must set QNH at the transition level.

Transition altitude = altitude at which the pilot in a climb changes from QNH to 1013.2/standard pressure.    
Transition level = lowest flight level available for use above the tranistion altitude.    
Transition level is the flight level at which the pilot in a desent changes altimeter setting from standard/1013.2 to QNH.

### Transition Layer

transition layer := layer between transition altitude and transition level.

transition altitude < transition layer < transition level 

within transition layer: vertical position should be expressed in terms of flight levels when ascending and in terms of altitude when descendeing.

variations exists.

### Pre-flight Operational Test

**QNH setting** - aircraft at known elevation on the aerodrome, set altimeter pressure scale to current QNH seting. Vibrate instrument by tapping unless mechanical vibration is provided ~~ -/+80ft for a 0-50.000ft altimeter

**QFE setting** - aircraft at known elevation on the aerodrome, set altimeter pressure scale to the current QFE. Vibrate insturment unless mechanical vibration is provided ~~ -/+ 80ft for 0-50.000ft altimeter.

-/+60ft for altimeter 0-30.000ft range.


### Take-off and Climb

QNH must be made available to aircraft as part of the taxi-clearance.    
Prior to take-off at least one altimeter must be set to the latest QNH altimeter setting for the aerodrome.

### Approach

During the approach to land terrain clearance may be detmined by using QNH (giving altitude) or - under specified circumstances - a QFE setting (gibving height above the QFE datum).


## Parallel Runway Operations

Near parallel runways are defined as non-intersecting runways whose extended center lines diverge or converge by 15 degrees or less.    
Rules apply equally to exactly paralle or near parallel runways.

### Parallel Approaches

**independent parallel approaches** = approaches which are made to parallel runway where radar separation minima between aircraft using adjacent ILS are not prescribed.

**dependent parallel approaches** = approaches which are made to parallel runways where radar separation minima between aircraft using adjacent ILS and/are prescribed.

### Parallel Departures

simultaneous departure for aircraft departing in the same direcetion from parallel runways.

### both parallel approaches and departures

3 sets of operations that allow both approaches and departures from parallel runways:     
- mixed    
- segregated     
- semi-mixed

**mixed operations** = simultaneous parallel approaches with departures interspersed on both runways      
**segregated operations** = exclusive use of one runway for approaches and the other for departures     
**semi-mixed operations** = either one runway used exclusively for departures, while the other ruenway accepts a mixture of approaches and depattures, or one runway is exclusively used for approaches and the other accepts a mix of departures and approaches.


### Simultaneous Independent Approach Procedures

simultaneous independent parallel approaches are in progress

* controller will issue instructions to ensure separation between aircraft and prevent aircraft from entering the NTZ;
* arriving aircraft will be vetored to one of the other of the parallel ILS localiser courses;
* when cleared for an ILS approach, a procedure turn is not permitted;
* the final vector must allow at least 1NM of straight and level flight before the localiser final approach track interception.
* the final vector must also enable the aircraft to be established on the ILS localiser course final approach track in level flight for at least 2NM prior to intercepting the ILS glidepath;
* each pari of parallel approaches will have a *high side* and a *low side* for vectoring to privde vertical eparation until aircraft are established inbound on their respective parallel ILS localiser course and/final approach track. The main objective is that both aircraft to be estabished on the ILS localiser course final approach track befor ethe 300m/1000ft vertical separation is reduced;
* if considered necessary, appropriate missed apporahc instructions will be issued.

Aircraft must be vectored ot be established on the localiser at least 2NM before the glide path interception.
